issues.description: The problem statement refers to a class named `Stock` (with methods add, take, findStockIngredient, etc.), but the template and solution repositories provide this functionality in a class named `Inventory`. Students looking for `Stock.java` will not find it and will be confused about which class to use or implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Either rename the template/solution class `Inventory` to `Stock` (and update all references), or update the problem statement to refer to an `Inventory` class instead of `Stock` to keep naming consistent across all artifacts.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to a class named 'Stock', but the provided template and solution code use a class named 'Inventory' for the same stock management concept. Students expecting to find or extend 'Stock' may be confused when the code only contains 'Inventory'.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the class 'Inventory' to 'Stock' (and adjust references accordingly) so that the code matches the problem statement and UML, or alternatively update the problem description to use 'Inventory' instead of 'Stock' for consistency.
